From: Shane Duan <sduan@...>

If you can provide more information, I might have a better answer.

What kind of 'certain type of compatibility' are you referring to?

'my code' mentioned in your earlier post is referring to your unit testing code
is that correct?

As to your question of add, I suspect that what you have learned in school is
in procedure language instead of object oriented language.  So if you have two
variable 'a' and 'b', in procedure language it is 'add(a, b)', while in object
oriented language it is 'a.add(b)'.  In fact, I think in the early days of C++
the compile just convert a.add(b) to add(a, b).

Hope that is clear.


Jason Rogers wrote:

> He said he was the author of the code, so I don't think that will work.
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Keith Ray [mailto:keith.ray@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, August 07, 2001 1:27 PM
> To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> Subject: [junit] re - novice QA
>
> >I am invading your group as a mere QA intern. . .  I am supposed to
> >implement JUnit tests on code that I have just written. However, what
> >I have learned in school does not seem to apply here!  We learned
> >that if the method is an "add" method, give it two numbers,
> >and "assert" that the correct addition is performed, and so on. . .
> >well, I have no clue what to assert!
> >
> >Quick rundown of what I am testing:
> >
> >Basically, my code is using the Reflection class to check all the
> >members of a class for a certain type of compatibility.  Most methods
> >add errors to an error vector, and then there is a simple print
> >function to print out the vector... How on earth do I test this
> >class??
> >
> >Thanks for any help in advance!!
> You should pair-program with the writer of this code to refactor it to be
> more testable. Search the web for "test-first-design", "test-first-coding",
> "refactoring", etc... search Ward's Wiki as well:
> <http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?FindPage>.
